revision.text:
{{For|the baseball player|Jim Brewer}} {{Infobox comedian | name = Jim Breuer | image = Jim Breuer headshot.jpg | imagesize = | caption = Breuer in 2017 | pseudonym = | birth_name = James E. Breuer | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1967|6|21}} | birth_place = [[Valley Stream, New York]] | death_date = | death_place = | medium = Stand-up, television, film, radio | nationality = American | active = 1988–present | genre = [[Observational comedy]], [[improvisational comedy]], [[character comedy]], [[music]] | subject = Everyday life, marriage, parenting, self-deprecation, music | influences = [[George Carlin]], [[Sam Kinison]], [[Steve Martin]], [[Bill Cosby]], [[Richard Pryor]]{{cite web|url=http://www.marksfriggin.com/news09/1-12.htm#tue|title=Jim Breuer Back On SIRIUS|publisher=MarksFriggin.com|author=Mercer, Mark|date=January 12, 2009|accessdate=January 14, 2009}} | influenced = | spouse = Dee Breuer (m. 1993) | children = 3 | notable_work= ''[[Saturday Night Live]]''
''[[Half Baked]]''
''Premium Blends''
''[[Web Junk 20]]''
''Fridays with Jim Breuer'' | signature = | website = [http://www.jimbreuer.com/ jimbreuer.com] | footnotes = }} '''James E. Breuer''' (born June 21, 1967) is an American [[Stand-up comedy|stand-up comedian]], actor, musician, and radio host. He was a cast member on ''[[Saturday Night Live]]'' from 1995 to 1998 and starred in the film ''[[Half Baked]]''. ==Early life== Breuer was born and raised in [[Valley Stream, New York|Valley Stream]], New York.{{cite web|url=http://www.starpulse.com/Actors/Breuer,_Jim/Biography/ |title=Jim Breuer Biography |publisher=Starpulse.com |date=June 21, 1967 |accessdate=August 3, 2010}} His father was a veteran of [[World War II]].{{cite web|url=http://www.dodlive.mil/index.php/2014/03/bacon-brothers-jim-breuer-honor-fathers-by-supporting-troops/ |title=Bacon Brothers, Jim Breuer Honor Fathers by Supporting Troops |publisher=DoDLive |date=March 25, 2014 |accessdate=June 23, 2015}} ==Career== ===Television career=== Breuer's career began on the little-known ''Uptown Comedy Club'' weekly television show, based in Harlem, New York.{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gGf-GtRtH6c |title=YouTube |publisher=YouTube |date= |accessdate=2014-05-18}} He then joined the a cast of ''[[Saturday Night Live]]'' from 1995 to 1998.{{cite web|url=http://comedians.comedycentral.com/jim-breuer |title=Jim Breuer: Stand Up Videos and Funny Clips | Comedy Central's Jokes.com |publisher=Comedians.comedycentral.com |date= |accessdate=August 3, 2010}} On ''SNL'', Breuer's characters included "[[Goat Boy]]" (who hosted the fictional MTV program "Hey, Remember the 80s?") and Glen Henderson, the elder brother to [[Chris Kattan]]'s Todd Henderson/Azrael Abyss character in the "[[Goth Talk]]" skits. He has previously guest starred in ''[[Home Improvement (TV series)|Home Improvement]]''. That appearance gave way to the short-lived sitcom ''[[Buddies (TV series)|Buddies]]''. He was originally scheduled to have been the co-star alongside friend and co-worker [[Dave Chappelle]], but was pulled from the role after filming the pilot. Among his impersonations was that of actor [[Joe Pesci]], who hosted his own talk show, often accompanied by [[Colin Quinn]] playing fellow actor [[Robert De Niro]]. In a 1997 episode of ''SNL'', both Pesci and De Niro made surprise appearances to "confront" Breuer. In 1998, Breuer hosted "The Jim Breuer Show" on MTV which aired week days at 5:30 PM and again at 1:00 AM during the summer. It included Breuer performing skits as different characters as well as stand-up comedy by guests including [[Judah Friedlander]], [[Jeff Ross]] and [[Tracy Morgan]].{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0165034/|title=The Jim Breuer Show (1998– )|publisher=IMDb.com|accessdate=2014-05-18}} Breuer has also hosted several "Premium Blends" on [[Comedy Central]] as well as several appearances on other comedy shows. Breuer hosted the third season of the [[VH1]] show ''[[Web Junk 20]]''. The season began on November 17, 2006. He replaced [[Patrice O'Neal]], who hosted the first two seasons of the show. In 2002, Breuer's first one-hour Comedy Central special, "Hardcore," premiered. The same year, he released a comedy album titled ''Smoke 'n' Breu''.{{cite web|author=Michael Cusanelli |url=http://allmusic.com/album/smoke-n-breu-r608281 |title=Smoke 'n' Breu - Jim Breuer | Songs, Reviews, Credits, Awards |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=2014-05-18}} On July 25, 2009, Breuer's second one-hour Comedy Central special, "Let's Clear the Air," premiered and came in as one of the highest rated comedy specials in Comedy Central's history. {{citation needed|date=February 2011}} Breuer appeared in [[Pizza Hut]] commercials, advertising the cheese crust-filled pizzas using the catch phrase "Jackpot!" Also, Breuer starred in the VH1 documentary ''[[When Ruled the World|When Metallica Ruled the World]]'' where he commented on the songs by Metallica through the years. Beginning in 2016, Breuer has appeared in the recurring role of Father Philip on the CBS sitcom ''[[Kevin Can Wait]]'', which is set and filmed in Breuer's native [[Nassau County, New York]]. ===Radio career=== Breuer was a sit-in comedian on the ''[[Opie and Anthony Show]]'' for many years during their [[WNEW-FM]] tenure. "Breuer Bits" were often played whenever the show was on hiatus.{{Citation needed|date=December 2007}} With the [[XM/Sirius merger]] complete, Breuer returned to the ''Opie and Anthony Show'' for the first time in six years on August 8, 2008.{{cite web |url=http://www.923krock.com/pages/1420414.php#fri |title=Opie and Anthony Show Rundown for August 8th, 2008|publisher=923krock.com|accessdate=2014-05-18}} He remained a frequent guest. Breuer is the host of ''Fridays with Jim Breuer,'' (previously known as ''Breuer Unleashed'') which can be heard each Friday afternoon from 4-6PM (EST) on the [[Sirius Satellite Radio]] channel "Raw Dog Comedy." He credits [[Joe Pesci]] with jump starting his career as he mentions in his comedy concert "Hardcore". During one show, while Breuer was singing the [[Judas Priest]] song "Devil's Child," [[Rob Halford]], lead singer of Judas Priest, entered the studio and joined Breuer in song.{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Y2bRzhkGNJI |title=Breuer and Halford Duet |publisher=YouTube |date= |accessdate=2014-05-18}} ===Other work=== In 2008, Breuer went on his first tour in six years known as the "Breuniversity Tour" where he toured over 20 colleges and comedy clubs across the country. The footage was used in his documentary ''More Than Me'', as well as his 4-hour DVD ''The Jim Breuer Road Journals,'' both of which were released in 2010. On October 5, 2010 he published a book called ''I'm Not High (But I've Got a Lot of Crazy Stories about Life as a Goat Boy, a Dad, and a Spiritual Warrior)''{{Cite book | last1 = Breuer | first1 = Jim | title = I'm Not High: (But I've Got a Lot of Crazy Stories about Life as a Goat Boy, a Dad, and a Spiritual Warrior) | date = October 5, 2010 | publisher = Gotham Books | location = New York | isbn = 978-1-59240-575-6 }} In January 2011, he launched a podcast called "The Podcast Masters" with fellow comedian [[Pete Correale]]. In December 2011, Breuer presented at [[Metallica]]'s 30th Anniversary shows. ==Personal life== He now lives in [[Chester Township, New Jersey]] with his wife, Dee, and three daughters.{{cite web |author=Keller, Joel |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9500E7D8173FF935A25753C1A9639C8B63 |title=In Person; Mr. Breuer's Neighborhood |publisher=The New York Times |date=October 16, 2005 |accessdate=October 28, 2007|quote="Mr. Breuer's stand-up comedy often revolves around stories about his childhood in Valley Stream, N.Y., on Long Island, his marriage and his neighbors. Living in Chester speaks to how he wants to live."}} He is an avid [[New York Mets]] fan who routinely posts videos in support of the team on his Facebook account. ==Discography== * Jim Breuer and The Loud & Rowdy - ''Songs From The Garage'' (2016; [[Metal Blade Records]]{{cite web|url=http://www.metalblade.com/us/artists/jim-breuer/|title=Jim Breuer and the Loud & Rowdy|publisher=[[Metal Blade Records]]|accessdate=January 17, 2017}}) Tracklist:
1.Thrash (Jim Breuer / Rob Caggiano / Joe Vigliotti)
2.Raising Teenage Girls (Jim Breuer / Rob Caggiano / Metal Mike Chlasciak/ Mike Tichy)
3.Old School (Jim Breuer / Rob Caggiano / Desmond Child /Metal Mike Chlasciak / Joan Jett)
4.Be a Dick 2nite (Jim Breuer / Rob Caggiano / Mike Tichy / Joe Vigliotti)
5.My Rock 'n Roll Dream (Jim Breuer / Rob Caggiano / Mike Tichy)
6.Mr. Rock 'n Roll (Jim Breuer / Rob Caggiano / Brian Johnson)
7.Who's Better Than Us?! (Jim Breuer / Rob Caggiano)
8.Family Warrior (Jim Breuer / Rob Caggiano / Chris Chicinno / Metal Mike Chlasciak)
9.Sugar Rush (Jim Breuer / Rob Caggiano / Mike Tichy)
10.Wannabe (Paul Bond / Jim Breuer / Rob Caggiano)
11.The Unexplained (Jim Breuer / Rob Caggiano / Larry Schneidmuller) Credits:
Jim Breuer: Vocals
Rob Caggiano: Guitars
Mike Tichy: Drums, Bg Vocals
Joe Vigliotti: Bass, Bg Vocals

Additional:
Brian Johnson: vocals on 5 & 6

Touring Band:
Jim Breuer: Vocals
Mike Tichy: Lead Guitar, Bg Vocals
Joe Vigliotti: Bass, Bg Vocals
Allison Woest: Rhythm Guitar
Eric See: Drums ==Filmography== * ''[[Clerks#Clerks: The TV Show|Clerks: The TV Show]]'' (1995) * ''[[Home Improvement (TV series)|Home Improvement]]'' (1995) * ''[[Buddies (TV series)|Buddies]]'' (replaced after pilot) (1997) * ''[[Half Baked]]'' (1998) * ''[[Dick (film)|Dick]]'' (1999) * ''[[Titan A.E.]]'' (2000) * ''[[Once in the Life]]'' (2000) * ''[[One Eyed King]]'' (2001) * ''[[American Dummy]]'' (2002) * ''[[Crooked Lines]]'' (2003) * ''[[Artie Lange's Beer League|Beer League]]'' (2006) * ''More than Me'' (2010) * ''[[Zookeeper (film)|Zookeeper]]'' (2011) * ''[[Motorcity]]'' (2012) * ''[[School Dance (film)|School Dance]]'' (2014) * ''[[Bling (film)|Bling]]'' (2016) * ''[[Kevin Can Wait]]'' (2016) * ''[[Liv & Maddie]]'' (2017) ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== * Official MySpace Page] * [https://www.youtube.com/Breuniverse Official YouTube Page] * [http://www.jesterjournal.com/IntBreuer1.htm Interview about 'More Than Me' documentary] *
